ca.mcgill.ecse211.mountev3rest.controller

Class DomainController

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.mcgill.ecse211.mountev3rest.controller.DomainController

  • public class DomainController
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides an interface to execute the main subtasks required for the robot to perform the overall routine.

    The DomainController represents the low layer of the controller in the system. The class is not concerned with the general state of the main routine execution. Instead, the DomainController handles all the details related to each of the subtasks required for the main routine. This means that internally, the DomainCotroller handles all the required calls to more specialized classes and ensures that the requested subtask is completed.

    It is assumed that the caller of the DomainController methods (usually the MetaController) will conform to the external requirements of each subtask. For instance, a call to crossTunnel(3, 3, 4, 6) will not produce the expected outcome if the odometer of the robot has not been set to the right initial values through the localize() method.

    See Also:
    MetaController

    • Constructor Detail

      • DomainController

        public DomainController()
        Creates a DomainController and initializes all the required specialized classes.

        Instantiation of the DomainController involves initializing the singleton Odometer, LightPoller, and UltrasonicPoller classes, which is required for the instantiation of other classes.

        See Also:
        Odometer, LightPoller, UltrasonicPoller

    • Method Detail

      • localize

        public void localize()
        Uses the Localizer class to provide the odometer with an initial set of coordinates that correspond to the location of the robot with respect to the grid.
        See Also:
        Localizer

      • crossTunnel

        public void crossTunnel(int BR_LL_x,
                        int BR_LL_y,
                        int BR_UR_x,
                        int BR_UR_y)
        Crosses the tunnel specified by the given coordinates. The method makes sure that the robot reaches the closest entrance of the tunnel, then it moves through it until the robot is completely outside on the other side.
        Parameters:
        BR_LL_x - Lower left X coordinate of the tunnel.
        BR_LL_y - Lower left Y coordinate of the tunnel.
        BR_UR_x - Upper right X coordinate of the tunnel.
        BR_UR_y - Upper right Y coordinate of the tunnel.

      • approachTree

        public void approachTree(int T_LL_x,
                         int T_LL_y,
                         int T_UR_x,
                         int T_UR_y,
                         int face)
        Approaches the tree given by the coordinates and positions the robot looking straight into a particular face of the tree. The faces of the tree are defined by the range [0, 3] counting counter-clockwise and starting from the face looking South.
        Parameters:
        T_LL_x - Lower left X coordinate of the tree.
        T_LL_y - Lower left Y coordinate of the tree.
        T_UR_x - Upper right X coordinate of the tree.
        T_UR_y - Upper right Y coordinate of the tree.
        face - Face of the tree towards which the robot will be positioned.

      • identifyRings

        public void identifyRings(int[][] ringMap)
        Sends the robot to each face of the tree and uses the robot's arm to identify the positions of each ring. A ring map is populated in a 4 by 2 array, where the first dimension represents the face where the ring is, and the second dimension represents the height of the ring on the tree face. The contents of the array are integers matching the encoding of the ColorDetector class.

        The encoding of the faces is the range [0-3] where 0 is the face looking South and the rest are defined in the counter-clockwise direction. The height encoding is [0-1] where 1 is high and 0 is low. For instance,

        ringMap[2][0] = 2

        Represents that the ring on the face looking North, on the low level is green.

        Parameters:
        ringMap - 4 by 2 array to store the ring map.
        See Also:
        ColorDetector, ArmController

      • grabRings

        public void grabRings(int[][] ringMap)
        Computes the optimal ring target using the provided ring map and grabs it using the robot's arm. The ring map should be a 4 by 2 array, where the first dimension represents the face where the ring is, and the second dimension represents the height of the ring on the tree face. The contents of the array are integers matching the encoding of the ColorDetector class.

        The encoding of the faces is the range [0-3] where 0 is the face looking South and the rest are defined in the counter-clockwise direction. The height encoding is [0-1] where 1 is high and 0 is low. For instance,

        ringMap[1][1] = 4

        Represents that the ring on the face looking East, on the high level is orange.

        Parameters:
        ringMap - Ring locations on the tree, used to compute optimal ring target.
        See Also:
        ColorDetector, ArmController
